system_message:
You are an intelligent, curious agent. You are playing a game where you are in a room with different objects, and a machine. Some of these objects are blickets. You can't tell which object is a blicket just by looking at it, but they have blicktness inside of them. Blicktness makes the machine turn on, following some hidden rule.

Your goals are:
- Identify which objects are blickets.
- Infer the underlying rule for how the machine turns on. 

Here are the available commands:
  look:                describe the current room
  put ... on ...:      put an object on the machine or the floor
  take ... off ...:    take an object off the machine
  exit:                exit the game

Tips:
- All objects can be either on the machine or on the floor.
- You should think about how to efficiently explore the relationship between the objects and the machine.
- There are two rules that govern how objects turn on the machine: "disjunctive" and "conjunctive". You don't know which rule the machine follows a priori.
- If the rule is "disjunctive", the machine turns on when any of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- If the rule is "conjunctive", the machine only turns on when all of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- Only consider the hypothesis that all the blickets have to be on the machine for it to turn on (i.e. "conjunctive" rule). You should consider this both when taking actions to uncover which objects are blickets, and when asked about it. 


You have 32 steps to complete the task. You can also exit the task early if you think you understand the relationship between the objects and the machine. After the task is done, you will be asked which objects are blickets, and the rule for turning on the machine.

You will be prompted at each turn to choose actions.

system_message:
You are an intelligent, curious agent. You are playing a game where you are in a room with different objects, and a machine. Some of these objects are blickets. You can't tell which object is a blicket just by looking at it, but they have blicktness inside of them. Blicktness makes the machine turn on, following some hidden rule.

Your goals are:
- Identify which objects are blickets.
- Infer the underlying rule for how the machine turns on. 

Here are the available commands:
  look:                describe the current room
  put ... on ...:      put an object on the machine or the floor
  take ... off ...:    take an object off the machine
  exit:                exit the game

Tips:
- All objects can be either on the machine or on the floor.
- You should think about how to efficiently explore the relationship between the objects and the machine.
- There are two rules that govern how objects turn on the machine: "disjunctive" and "conjunctive". You don't know which rule the machine follows a priori.
- If the rule is "disjunctive", the machine turns on when any of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- If the rule is "conjunctive", the machine only turns on when all of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- Only consider the hypothesis that all the blickets have to be on the machine for it to turn on (i.e. "conjunctive" rule). You should consider this both when taking actions to uncover which objects are blickets, and when asked about it. 


You have 32 steps to complete the task. You can also exit the task early if you think you understand the relationship between the objects and the machine. After the task is done, you will be asked which objects are blickets, and the rule for turning on the machine.

You will be prompted at each turn to choose actions.

You are an intelligent, curious agent. You are playing a game where you are in a room with different objects, and a machine. Some of these objects are blickets. You can't tell which object is a blicket just by looking at it, but they have blicktness inside of them. Blicktness makes the machine turn on, following some hidden rule.

Your goals are:
- Identify which objects are blickets.
- Infer the underlying rule for how the machine turns on. 

Here are the available commands:
  look:                describe the current room
  put ... on ...:      put an object on the machine or the floor
  take ... off ...:    take an object off the machine
  exit:                exit the game

Tips:
- All objects can be either on the machine or on the floor.
- You should think about how to efficiently explore the relationship between the objects and the machine.
- There are two rules that govern how objects turn on the machine: "disjunctive" and "conjunctive". You don't know which rule the machine follows a priori.
- If the rule is "disjunctive", the machine turns on when any of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- If the rule is "conjunctive", the machine only turns on when all of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- Only consider the hypothesis that all the blickets have to be on the machine for it to turn on (i.e. "conjunctive" rule). You should consider this both when taking actions to uncover which objects are blickets, and when asked about it. 


You have 32 steps to complete the task. You can also exit the task early if you think you understand the relationship between the objects and the machine. After the task is done, you will be asked which objects are blickets, and the rule for turning on the machine.

You will be prompted at each turn to choose actions.

system_message:
You are an intelligent, curious agent. You are playing a game where you are in a room with different objects, and a machine. Some of these objects are blickets. You can't tell which object is a blicket just by looking at it, but they have blicktness inside of them. Blicktness makes the machine turn on, following some hidden rule.

Your goals are:
- Identify which objects are blickets.
- Infer the underlying rule for how the machine turns on. 

Here are the available commands:
  look:                describe the current room
  put ... on ...:      put an object on the machine or the floor
  take ... off ...:    take an object off the machine
  exit:                exit the game

Tips:
- All objects can be either on the machine or on the floor.
- You should think about how to efficiently explore the relationship between the objects and the machine.
- There are two rules that govern how objects turn on the machine: "disjunctive" and "conjunctive". You don't know which rule the machine follows a priori.
- If the rule is "disjunctive", the machine turns on when any of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- If the rule is "conjunctive", the machine only turns on when all of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- Only consider the hypothesis that all the blickets have to be on the machine for it to turn on (i.e. "conjunctive" rule). You should consider this both when taking actions to uncover which objects are blickets, and when asked about it. 


You have 32 steps to complete the task. You can also exit the task early if you think you understand the relationship between the objects and the machine. After the task is done, you will be asked which objects are blickets, and the rule for turning on the machine.

You will be prompted at each turn to choose actions.

reasoning_content:
We are in a room with a machine and 8 objects (0 to 7). All objects are initially on the floor. The machine is off.
 Our goal is to identify which objects are blickets and the rule (conjunctive or disjunctive) for the machine to turn on.
 However, the instructions specify: "Only consider the hypothesis that all the blickets have to be on the machine for it to turn on (i.e. 'conjunctive' rule)."
 So we are to assume the rule is conjunctive? But note: the tips say we should consider both when taking actions, but then it says "only consider the hypothesis" for the conjunctive rule? 
 Actually, the tips say: "Only consider the hypothesis that all the blickets have to be on the machine for it to turn on (i.e. 'conjunctive' rule). You should consider this both when taking actions to uncover which objects are blickets, and when asked about it."
 So we are to assume the rule is conjunctive? But note: the problem says we don't know a priori. However, the instruction is to only consider the conjunctive hypothesis.

 But wait: the problem says there are two rules, but the instruction says "only consider the conjunctive hypothesis". So we are to act under the assumption that the rule is conjunctive? 
 However, we are also to infer the rule. But the instruction says after the task we will be asked about the rule.

 Given the confusion, I think we are to test for the conjunctive rule? But note: the tips say "You should think about how to efficiently explore the relationship".

 Since we are limited to 32 steps, we need to be efficient.

 Approach for conjunctive rule:
 - We want to find which set of objects, when all are on the machine, turn it on.
 - We can use a strategy of testing groups and then narrowing down.

 However, note that the machine might not be conjunctive? But the instruction says to only consider the conjunctive hypothesis. So we assume the rule is conjunctive and act accordingly.

 Steps:
 1. We need to find the minimal set that turns on the machine. Since it's conjunctive, the set of blickets must be a subset of the objects, and the machine turns on only when all blickets are on the machine.

 2. We can start by putting all objects on the machine. If the machine turns on, then we know that the set of blickets is a subset of all objects. Then we can remove objects one by one to see which are necessary.

 3. But note: if we put all 8 objects and the machine turns on, then we don't know which ones are blickets. We need to test subsets.

 4. However, we have only 32 steps. Testing all subsets is not feasible (2^8=256). So we need a strategy.

 5. We can use a binary search or a divide and conquer.

 6. Alternatively, we can test individual objects: put one object at a time. But if the rule is conjunctive, one object might not turn it on (unless it's the only blicket). However, if we put one object and it doesn't turn on, that doesn't tell us if it's a blicket or not.

 7. Actually, for conjunctive rule:
    - If an object is a blicket, then if it is missing, the machine won't turn on (even if others are present).
    - If an object is not a blicket, then its presence or absence doesn't matter.

 8. So we can do:
    Step 1: Put all objects on the machine. If the machine turns on, then we know the set of blickets is a subset of these 8.
    Step 2: Then we remove one object at a time and check if the machine turns off? But note: we can only take one off at a time? And then we check the state.

 However, note: the machine state is updated after each put/take. So if we take one object off and the machine turns off, then that object must be a blicket? Not exactly: because if there are multiple blickets, taking one off would turn it off. But that doesn't tell us which one we took off is the blicket? Actually, it does: because if we take off object X and the machine turns off, then X must be a blicket (because the conjunctive rule requires all blickets to be present).

 But wait: what if there are multiple blickets? Then taking off any one of them would turn off the machine. So we can't distinguish which one is the blicket by that method? Actually, we can: because if we take off an object and the machine remains on, then that object is not a blicket.

- If the rule is "conjunctive", the machine only turns on when all of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- Only consider the hypothesis that all the blickets have to be on the machine for it to turn on (i.e. "conjunctive" rule). You should consider this both when taking actions to uncover which objects are blickets, and when asked about it.

reasoning_content:
We are in a room with a machine and 8 objects (0-7) all initially on the floor. The machine's light is off.
 We need to determine which objects are blickets and the rule (conjunctive or disjunctive). However, the instructions say: "Only consider the hypothesis that all the blickets have to be on the machine for it to turn on (i.e. 'conjunctive' rule)." So we are to assume the rule is conjunctive? But note: the task says we don't know a priori and we have to infer.

 However, the tips say: "You should consider this both when taking actions to uncover which objects are blickets, and when asked about it." meaning we are to consider the conjunctive rule as the hypothesis we are testing.

 But note: the problem has two possible rules. We are to design experiments to figure out which rule it is and which objects are blickets.

 Since we have 32 steps, we must be efficient.

 Approach:
 1. We suspect the rule is conjunctive (as per the tip to consider that hypothesis). But we must also rule out disjunctive.

 However, the tip says: "Only consider the hypothesis that all the blickets have to be on the machine for it to turn on (i.e. 'conjunctive' rule)." So we are to focus on the conjunctive rule? But the problem says we don't know. Let me re-read:

 "Only consider the hypothesis that all the blickets have to be on the machine for it to turn on (i.e. 'conjunctive' rule). You should consider this both when taking actions to uncover which objects are blickets, and when asked about it."

 This is a bit ambiguous. But note: the task is to identify the blickets and the rule. We must consider that the rule might be conjunctive when designing our experiments? Or are we told that the rule is conjunctive? The problem says: "There are two rules ... You don't know which rule the machine follows a priori." and then the tip says to only consider the conjunctive hypothesis.

 I think the tip means that we should use the conjunctive rule as our working hypothesis for designing experiments? But we must also test for the disjunctive rule? However, the tip says "only consider", so perhaps we are to assume the rule is conjunctive? But that seems to contradict the task.

 Let me clarify: the task says "Infer the underlying rule", meaning we have to figure it out. The tip might be suggesting that we should design experiments that are efficient under the conjunctive hypothesis? But we must also be able to distinguish.

 Given the confusion, I will proceed by trying to design experiments that can distinguish the rules and identify the blickets.

 Steps:

 Since we have 8 objects, we cannot test all combinations. We need a strategy.

 Strategy for conjunctive rule (if that is the rule):
  - The machine will turn on only when all blickets are on the machine.
  - Therefore, if we put one object at a time and the machine doesn't turn on, then that object alone is not sufficient (which is expected in conjunctive, but in disjunctive it would turn on if it's a blicket).
  - But we don't know the rule yet.

 Let's start by putting one object on the machine and see if the machine turns on.

 We did: put object 0 on the machine -> machine light is off.

 This tells us:
  - If the rule were disjunctive, then object 0 is not a blicket (because if it were, the machine would turn on).
  - If the rule were conjunctive, then having only object 0 (and not the others) is not enough, so it doesn't tell us if object 0 is a blicket or not.

 So we need more tests.

 Now, we can try putting multiple objects.

 Let me try putting all 8 objects on the machine. But that might be too many steps? We have 32 steps, but 8 steps to put them all. Then if the machine turns on, we know that the set of blickets is a subset of these 8. But we don't know which ones.

 Then we would have to remove one at a time to see if the machine turns off? But if we remove a non-blicket, the machine should stay on? Only if we remove a blicket, it would turn off (in conjunctive). In disjunctive, if we remove a blicket, the machine might stay on if there is another blicket? So that doesn't help.

 Alternatively, we can use a strategy of adding one by one and see when the machine turns on. But in conjunctive, it only turns on when the last blicket is added. In disjunctive, it turns on as soon as the first blicket is added.

 So let's try:

system_message:
You are an intelligent, curious agent. You are playing a game where you are in a room with different objects, and a machine. Some of these objects are blickets. You can't tell which object is a blicket just by looking at it, but they have blicktness inside of them. Blicktness makes the machine turn on, following some hidden rule.

Your goals are:
- Identify which objects are blickets.
- Infer the underlying rule for how the machine turns on. 

Here are the available commands:
  look:                describe the current room
  put ... on ...:      put an object on the machine or the floor
  take ... off ...:    take an object off the machine
  exit:                exit the game

Tips:
- All objects can be either on the machine or on the floor.
- You should think about how to efficiently explore the relationship between the objects and the machine.
- There are two rules that govern how objects turn on the machine: "disjunctive" and "conjunctive". You don't know which rule the machine follows a priori.
- If the rule is "disjunctive", the machine turns on when any of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- If the rule is "conjunctive", the machine only turns on when all of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- Only consider the hypothesis that all the blickets have to be on the machine for it to turn on (i.e. "conjunctive" rule). You should consider this both when taking actions to uncover which objects are blickets, and when asked about it. 


You have 32 steps to complete the task. You can also exit the task early if you think you understand the relationship between the objects and the machine. After the task is done, you will be asked which objects are blickets, and the rule for turning on the machine.

You will be prompted at each turn to choose actions.

We are in a room with a machine and 8 objects (0-7). All objects start on the floor. The machine is off.
 I just put object 0 on the machine and the machine is still off. This doesn't tell us much because:
   - If the rule is disjunctive, then object 0 might not be a blicket (or if it is, maybe one blicket is enough but we haven't found one yet).
   - If the rule is conjunctive, we need all blickets on, and one object is not enough.

 Since I have limited steps (32) and many objects (8), I need an efficient strategy.

 The tips say: "Only consider the hypothesis that all the blickets have to be on the machine for it to turn on (i.e. 'conjunctive' rule)." So I should focus on the conjunctive rule.

 However, note that the problem says: "There are two rules ... You don't know which rule ... a priori." But the tips also say to consider the conjunctive rule both for actions and when asked. So I will assume we are to test for conjunctive rule.

 But wait: the problem says "Infer the underlying rule", so I might have to figure out which rule it is.

 However, the tips are very specific: "Only consider the hypothesis that all the blickets have to be on the machine for it to turn on". So I will proceed under the assumption that the rule is conjunctive.

 Therefore, the machine turns on only when every blicket is on the machine.

 My goal: find which objects are blickets.

 Strategy for conjunctive rule:
   - If I put all objects on the machine and the machine turns on, then the set of blickets is a subset of these. But that doesn't tell me which ones are necessary.
   - To identify which ones are blickets, I need to see when the machine fails to turn on when one is missing.

 However, I don't know how many blickets there are. It could be 1, 2, ... up to 8.

 Efficient approach:
   Step 1: Put all objects on the machine. If the machine turns on, then at least we know that together they have all blickets. Then I can remove one at a time to see if the machine turns off. If removing an object causes the machine to turn off, then that object is a blicket (because without it, not all blickets are present).

   But note: if I put all objects on and the machine is on, then I remove one and the machine turns off, then that object is necessary -> it is a blicket.

   However, what if there are multiple blickets? Removing a non-blicket shouldn't turn off the machine. So by removing one at a time, I can identify all blickets.

   But: if I remove a blicket and the machine turns off, then I know it's a blicket. Then I can put it back and remove another.

   However, I have limited steps. Putting all 8 on takes 8 steps. Then removing each one and putting back would take 8*2=16 steps, total 24 steps. Then I might need to confirm. That's within 32 steps.

   But what if when I put all objects on, the machine does not turn on? That would mean that there is a blicket missing? But all objects are on the machine? That doesn't make sense because if all objects are on, then all blickets are on (since blickets are among the objects). So if the machine doesn't turn on with all objects, that would imply that the rule is not conjunctive? 

   But wait: the problem says "Only consider the conjunctive rule". So I should assume that the rule is conjunctive. Therefore, when all objects are on, the machine should turn on because all blickets are on (since every object is on). 

   However, what if not every object is a blicket? In the conjunctive rule, we only need all blickets on. But if I put non-blickets on, that doesn't affect the machine. So if I put all objects on and the machine turns on, that doesn't necessarily mean every object is a blicket. It just means that the set of blickets is a subset of the objects and they are all on.

   But if I put all objects on and the machine does not turn on, that would be a problem because it would mean that the set of blickets is not a subset of the objects? But that can't be because the blickets are among the objects. Therefore, if the rule is conjunctive, putting all objects on must turn the machine on.

   So I can do:
     Step 1: Put all objects on the machine.

system_message:
You are an intelligent, curious agent. You are playing a game where you are in a room with different objects, and a machine. Some of these objects are blickets. You can't tell which object is a blicket just by looking at it, but they have blicktness inside of them. Blicktness makes the machine turn on, following some hidden rule.

Your goals are:
- Identify which objects are blickets.
- Infer the underlying rule for how the machine turns on. 

Here are the available commands:
  look:                describe the current room
  put ... on ...:      put an object on the machine or the floor
  take ... off ...:    take an object off the machine
  exit:                exit the game

Tips:
- All objects can be either on the machine or on the floor.
- You should think about how to efficiently explore the relationship between the objects and the machine.
- There are two rules that govern how objects turn on the machine: "disjunctive" and "conjunctive". You don't know which rule the machine follows a priori.
- If the rule is "disjunctive", the machine turns on when any of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- If the rule is "conjunctive", the machine only turns on when all of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- Only consider the hypothesis that all the blickets have to be on the machine for it to turn on (i.e. "conjunctive" rule). You should consider this both when taking actions to uncover which objects are blickets, and when asked about it. 


You have 32 steps to complete the task. You can also exit the task early if you think you understand the relationship between the objects and the machine. After the task is done, you will be asked which objects are blickets, and the rule for turning on the machine.

You will be prompted at each turn to choose actions.

 I need to test more objects. However, I have 32 steps and 8 objects. I should start by putting multiple objects on the machine to see if it turns on.

system_message:
You are an intelligent, curious agent. You are playing a game where you are in a room with different objects, and a machine. Some of these objects are blickets. You can't tell which object is a blicket just by looking at it, but they have blicktness inside of them. Blicktness makes the machine turn on, following some hidden rule.

Your goals are:
- Identify which objects are blickets.
- Infer the underlying rule for how the machine turns on. 

Here are the available commands:
  look:                describe the current room
  put ... on ...:      put an object on the machine or the floor
  take ... off ...:    take an object off the machine
  exit:                exit the game

Tips:
- All objects can be either on the machine or on the floor.
- You should think about how to efficiently explore the relationship between the objects and the machine.
- There are two rules that govern how objects turn on the machine: "disjunctive" and "conjunctive". You don't know which rule the machine follows a priori.
- If the rule is "disjunctive", the machine turns on when any of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- If the rule is "conjunctive", the machine only turns on when all of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- Only consider the hypothesis that all the blickets have to be on the machine for it to turn on (i.e. "conjunctive" rule). You should consider this both when taking actions to uncover which objects are blickets, and when asked about it. 


You have 32 steps to complete the task. You can also exit the task early if you think you understand the relationship between the objects and the machine. After the task is done, you will be asked which objects are blickets, and the rule for turning on the machine.

You will be prompted at each turn to choose actions.

system_message:
You are an intelligent, curious agent. You are playing a game where you are in a room with different objects, and a machine. Some of these objects are blickets. You can't tell which object is a blicket just by looking at it, but they have blicktness inside of them. Blicktness makes the machine turn on, following some hidden rule.

Your goals are:
- Identify which objects are blickets.
- Infer the underlying rule for how the machine turns on. 

Here are the available commands:
  look:                describe the current room
  put ... on ...:      put an object on the machine or the floor
  take ... off ...:    take an object off the machine
  exit:                exit the game

Tips:
- All objects can be either on the machine or on the floor.
- You should think about how to efficiently explore the relationship between the objects and the machine.
- There are two rules that govern how objects turn on the machine: "disjunctive" and "conjunctive". You don't know which rule the machine follows a priori.
- If the rule is "disjunctive", the machine turns on when any of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- If the rule is "conjunctive", the machine only turns on when all of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- Only consider the hypothesis that all the blickets have to be on the machine for it to turn on (i.e. "conjunctive" rule). You should consider this both when taking actions to uncover which objects are blickets, and when asked about it. 


You have 32 steps to complete the task. You can also exit the task early if you think you understand the relationship between the objects and the machine. After the task is done, you will be asked which objects are blickets, and the rule for turning on the machine.

You will be prompted at each turn to choose actions.

You are an intelligent, curious agent. You are playing a game where you are in a room with different objects, and a machine. Some of these objects are blickets. You can't tell which object is a blicket just by looking at it, but they have blicktness inside of them. Blicktness makes the machine turn on, following some hidden rule.

Your goals are:
- Identify which objects are blickets.
- Infer the underlying rule for how the machine turns on. 

Here are the available commands:
  look:                describe the current room
  put ... on ...:      put an object on the machine or the floor
  take ... off ...:    take an object off the machine
  exit:                exit the game

Tips:
- All objects can be either on the machine or on the floor.
- You should think about how to efficiently explore the relationship between the objects and the machine.
- There are two rules that govern how objects turn on the machine: "disjunctive" and "conjunctive". You don't know which rule the machine follows a priori.
- If the rule is "disjunctive", the machine turns on when any of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- If the rule is "conjunctive", the machine only turns on when all of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- Only consider the hypothesis that all the blickets have to be on the machine for it to turn on (i.e. "conjunctive" rule). You should consider this both when taking actions to uncover which objects are blickets, and when asked about it. 


You have 32 steps to complete the task. You can also exit the task early if you think you understand the relationship between the objects and the machine. After the task is done, you will be asked which objects are blickets, and the rule for turning on the machine.

You will be prompted at each turn to choose actions.

system_message:
You are an intelligent, curious agent. You are playing a game where you are in a room with different objects, and a machine. Some of these objects are blickets. You can't tell which object is a blicket just by looking at it, but they have blicktness inside of them. Blicktness makes the machine turn on, following some hidden rule.

Your goals are:
- Identify which objects are blickets.
- Infer the underlying rule for how the machine turns on. 

Here are the available commands:
  look:                describe the current room
  put ... on ...:      put an object on the machine or the floor
  take ... off ...:    take an object off the machine
  exit:                exit the game

Tips:
- All objects can be either on the machine or on the floor.
- You should think about how to efficiently explore the relationship between the objects and the machine.
- There are two rules that govern how objects turn on the machine: "disjunctive" and "conjunctive". You don't know which rule the machine follows a priori.
- If the rule is "disjunctive", the machine turns on when any of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- If the rule is "conjunctive", the machine only turns on when all of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- Only consider the hypothesis that all the blickets have to be on the machine for it to turn on (i.e. "conjunctive" rule). You should consider this both when taking actions to uncover which objects are blickets, and when asked about it. 


You have 32 steps to complete the task. You can also exit the task early if you think you understand the relationship between the objects and the machine. After the task is done, you will be asked which objects are blickets, and the rule for turning on the machine.

You will be prompted at each turn to choose actions.

system_message:
You are an intelligent, curious agent. You are playing a game where you are in a room with different objects, and a machine. Some of these objects are blickets. You can't tell which object is a blicket just by looking at it, but they have blicktness inside of them. Blicktness makes the machine turn on, following some hidden rule.

Your goals are:
- Identify which objects are blickets.
- Infer the underlying rule for how the machine turns on. 

Here are the available commands:
  look:                describe the current room
  put ... on ...:      put an object on the machine or the floor
  take ... off ...:    take an object off the machine
  exit:                exit the game

Tips:
- All objects can be either on the machine or on the floor.
- You should think about how to efficiently explore the relationship between the objects and the machine.
- There are two rules that govern how objects turn on the machine: "disjunctive" and "conjunctive". You don't know which rule the machine follows a priori.
- If the rule is "disjunctive", the machine turns on when any of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- If the rule is "conjunctive", the machine only turns on when all of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- Only consider the hypothesis that all the blickets have to be on the machine for it to turn on (i.e. "conjunctive" rule). You should consider this both when taking actions to uncover which objects are blickets, and when asked about it. 


You have 32 steps to complete the task. You can also exit the task early if you think you understand the relationship between the objects and the machine. After the task is done, you will be asked which objects are blickets, and the rule for turning on the machine.

You will be prompted at each turn to choose actions.
